I would suggest using video conference and/or Skype.  I would also suggest one on one with the person who is actually doing the work or needing the help.  They should be talking to the person who is making the decisions.  So the worker needs to make sure that any requests, concerns, suggestions, etc. that they have tried or did float up to the next in the organizational chart, is followed up to the next in the chain or the person making the decisions.  For example, Manager needing to hire another worker and has communicated that directly to the Supervisor (manager's boss).  This request goes on for a year or so with nothing happening.  Turns out that the Supervisor never relayed the request to her boss or the person who would be making the decision to hire another worker.  Manager should have followed up with the person who would be making the decision as to whether or not they would be able to hire another worker.

If the branches are far apart enough that a direct phone line is not an option, the company could create a radio device and simply transmit on a specific frequency. A "man in the middle" could not alter a radio wave, and if anything suspicious happens you could just change the frequency.

If the company is small, have a meeting area where people can talk face-to-face. But check the acoustics. Or encourage them to use landlines (cells can be hacked). Faxing is also an option. A ticker-tape machine could be adapted perhaps. Or you could go an encryption route-- have everyone learn Navaho (the Japanese didn't crack that in WWII) or develop a device that would encrypt-- but learn some lessons from the Enigma machine (WWII) and don't enable people to use personally meaningful passwords-- most importantly don't simply tell them not to. Perhaps LastPass or similar would help. The real problm is the "wetware" -the person. They can only tolerate so much cognitive load and that eventually undermines security systems. They also need support in sustaining a system.

First, the company should consider how well the protocol is in defending some well-known attack. Could the attacker forge the communication so that it can set up a transparent proxy in the middle of the channel? Second, the company should consider how secure the encryption algorithm is. For example, is it easy to do the cryptanalysis on cipher only text? is it easy to crack the algorithm if the attacker get the plain text and cipher text? Second, the insider attack should also be consider.

This is rather vague, but I will try to answer it.    The branches have an encryption mechanism to encrypt the messages that out of each office. Each office has its own encryption key that changes to predetermined encryption keys at regular intervals (say, every 12 hours). The other offices have also the list of the corresponding DEcryption keys that need to be used to decrypt the messages on their end. Since they are aware of the keys, no additional communication needs to take place. If the message is intercepted, it cannot be decrypted, as it requires the decryption key.

occupation: Assistant Adjunct Professor,  Pace University,  and Computer Science PhD student, Pace University

Idea: htey can use Lync or skype to communicate with each office.

Peer to peer chat communication with end to end encryption would be a good place to start...though there are exploits that target TLS to try and get around SSL / TSL via man in the middle attacks you can't have secure communication without strong encryption. To build upon this idea can have chat clients where people have unique identifiers that only allow them to communicate with those they have chosen to communicate with up front very similar to the way the Signal app uses your mobile address book to prove you know and hence can connect with some one.

The company could implement a secondary measure to ensure that communication is not interrupted, such as a secure token, delivered via text or voicemail, in order to initiate a conversation. Both users would need access to the private token in order to begin a tcp handshake, at which point the dialog could begin.

For every new communication, before the communication can start, both parties need to go through some 'security questions' check and then they need to answer some questions (e.g. given 9 pictures, they need to select those pictures with store front). Upon successful verification, then only the communication can begin.

To prevent middle attacks, the company could use hybrid cryptosystem - in which the identity of the sender and receiver are protected through RSA method with Public and private Key, while the message is protected using hash method.

To avoid mid attack,I suggest to get a dedicated bandwidth, for example, for police, a special bandwidth or vpn kind of private channel to provide secure realtime communication. For general companies, vpn is highly recommended.

1. Encrypt all the messages and use secret keys to identify valid users, and change the keys frequently. 2. Make sure the endpoint is safe, and always have several backup endpoints standing by. 3. Make sure database is not accessible through messages. 4. Do not save important data (like financial data, medical data, etc) directly. Transfer those data to somewhere else and only save the access token.
